justification: "To evaluate the impact of group communication, we analyzed the pre- and post-conversation responses of group members using three different outcome measures: 1) individual stay/switch behavior…" – stay/switch is explicitly named as an outcome measure used to quantify information exchange, i.e., communication success.
The same sentence lists "group and pair convergence within the group" as an outcome measure; convergence between disagreeing pairs is therefore used to measure the success of information exchange.
Outcome measures included "group and pair convergence within the group"; the group-level convergence score is thus treated as a metric of successful communication.

measured_by: group voting strategy metric (majority voting vs. confidence slating)
justification: The authors identify "3) the group’s voting strategy" as a third outcome measure and state that, together with the other metrics, it "quantif[ies] the extent and nature of information exchange among participants," linking it to communication success.

Participants "provided a confidence level, expressed as a percentage between 50 % and 100 %… asked to interpret the scale as indicating their estimated probability of having answered the question correctly, i.e. a metacognitive judgment,” showing the scale is the instrument for measuring decision confidence.
